Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Investigating the Relationship Between Mantle Shear Localization, Melt Flow and Water Content
Award.AbstractNarration:
The occurrence of shear localization is one of the defining properties of plate tectonics, but the mechanisms driving shear localization are poorly constrained. Both melt and water have been proposed as agents that lead to ductile localization within the Earth?s mantle. This CAREER research project investigates the relationship between shear localization, melt flow and water through analysis of well-preserved shear zones in one of the best examples of mantle peridotite, the Josephine peridotite in Oregon. Terrestrial laser scanning will be used to map shear zones at high resolution, with the survey being carried out as part of an undergraduate field class. The survey results will be merged with GPS data on the location and orientation of shear zones and melt channels. Microstructural analysis of samples collected during fieldwork will be carried out to determine the relationship between mineral orientations and variations in melt and water contents. Analysis of water concentrations in peridotite pyroxenes will be used to constrain the outcrop-scale variation in water in relation to shear deformation. The education component of this CAREER project will provide undergraduate and graduate students with experience in advanced field methods through the use of terrestrial laser scanning. Experience with cutting-edge analytical techniques and field campaign planning will prepare students for future careers in the geosciences. Integration of teaching and research in this project will expose students to a variety of topics and techniques across a range of disciplines, including petrology, geochemistry, rock deformation, tectonics and seismology.

The research in this proposal lies at the intersection of petrology, geochemistry, rock deformation, tectonics, and seismology. Project results will be widely applicable across disciplines. For example, the combination of microstructural analyses with peridotite geochemistry will provide insight into the factors that control seismic anisotropy. Results of this project will also be applicable to themes identified in the 2011 GeoPRISMS Implementation Plan, including (i) understanding mantle wedge dynamics; (ii) fore-arc to back-arc volatile fluxes and (iii) metamorphism, melting, and fluid/melt migration in the mantle wedge.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the relationship between shear localization, melt flow and water content through analysis of mantle shear zones in the Josephine Peridotite in Oregon, USA. The relationship between deformation, melt, and water is central to understanding the driving forces behind melt segregation and shear localization in the Earth?s upper mantle. In addition, the presence of melt and water impact seismic anisotropy, which is an important tool for mapping mantle flow.

The goals of this project were to:

  1. Constrain spatial relationships between shear zones, melt conduits, and water content.
  2. Evaluate the degree to which shear localization is controlled by the presence of water and melt.
  3. Explore the effects of water, melt, pyroxene content, and pre-existing texture on olivine crystallographic alignment and seismic anisotropy.
  4. Train students in advanced field techniques, cutting-edge laboratory techniques, and method development.
  5. Create reference materials for the analysis of water in nominally anhydrous minerals (NAMs).

A total of 22 students and 3 postdoctoral scientists from 8 institutions were involved in this project. Participants included women, under-represented minorities, and first generation college students. Eight undergraduates and 14 graduate students received training in advanced field techniques, including analysis of ultramafic rocks in the field and approaches for fine-scale mapping (GPS, terrestrial laser scanning, drone, and traditional mapping). Four graduate students received advanced training in analytical techniques, including technique development. Three postdoctoral scientists, all now in permanent positions in STEM fields, gained experience in organizing fieldwork, collecting data, presenting at conferences, publishing, and mentoring students.

Results from this project were disseminated through 16 publications and 41 conference presentations, as well as public talks and interviews with campus publications. This project was the basis for one PhD thesis, one undergraduate thesis, one undergraduate summer project, and contributed material to a PhD thesis chapter and two Master?s theses.

Major project results include constraints on the influence of water and melt for shear localization, based on sampling and analysis of the Josephine Peridotite shear zones. Skemer et al. (2013) showed that increased hydrogen contents in olivine could have initiated shear localization, but that viscous anisotropy was also necessary. Hansen and Warren (2015) constrained the influence of pyroxene content on olivine deformation. Kumamoto et al. (2019, G-Cubed) found that melt was the source of hydration in the shear zones. However, while shear initiation was controlled by the presence of melt and associated hydration of NAMs, additional mechanisms were necessary to fully localize shear. Kumamoto et al. (2019, JGR) showed that the dominant olivine slip system is not linked to strain or water content in the shear zones. Instead, olivine crystallographic preferred orientations (CPOs) reflect the effects of a pre-existing CPO and shear zone kinematics. Nevitt et al. (2019) explored the constitutive behavior of olivine in the shear zones, concluding that the presence of pyroxene may have expanded the range of conditions for which grain boundary sliding in olivine could operate. Finally, results from an undergraduate thesis indicate that changes in olivine CPO in melt-rich shear zones are due to higher olivine hydrogen contents cause by the melt.

This project provides constraints from natural samples on factors controlling seismic anisotropy. Hansen et al. (2016, EPSL) showed that mantle viscous anisotropy (the weakening induced by the alignment of olivine lattices) results from crystallographic textures in peridotites, providing a database of the textural and mechanical evolution of olivine as a function of strain. Hansen et al. (2016, JGR) presented a pair of models for the textural and mechanical evolution of viscous anisotropy, which were calibrated with this database and tested against Josephine Peridotite datasets. Hansen et al. (2016, PNAS) showed that upper mantle seismic properties vary when small amounts of melt are present and that this effect can match seismic observations of the Gutenberg discontinuity.

This project provides constraints on the presence of water as hydrogen in NAMs. Warren and Hauri (2014) demonstrated that pyroxene hydrogen content in abyssal and orogenic peridotites provides constraints on upper mantle water variations. They also showed that olivine has diffusively lost water, but that original olivine hydrogen contents can be calculated from pyroxene contents. Warren (2016) presented a global compilation of abyssal peridotite compositions, providing a basis for further analysis of water in NAMs. Lynn and Warren (2021) presented models of NAM rehydration timescales during melt-rock interaction. These models indicate that re-equilibration in the presence of melt occurs in minutes to days over the temperature range 800-1200C.

Kumamoto et al. (2017, Am Mineral) presented a new set of reference materials for the analysis of volatiles in orthopyroxene, olivine, and clinopyroxene. Mineral separates of these reference materials were prepared and transferred to the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History so that other labs can request them. A reference material mount (NMNH catalog number 118331) was also donated so that users can cross-calibrate mounts.
